So here's the problem with all of that:
1) These "single crypto transactions" don't exist, yet they form the base of the anti-crypto argument. You cannot have a transaction on the network that only moves crypto from one account to another, it doesn't work like that. They bundle transactions together at a set rate, or epoch, ie a predetermined number of transactions will happen every single day, regardless of how many nft's, trades, or other data is carried out on the network. So when they say a single transaction uses this much energy, they are really looking at the power to move Millions of dollars around from millions of users in countries all over the world. Then they take this power estimate, and they foolishly multiply it by the total number of transactions that happen in a day, month or year. But again, this is ridiculous, because there are really a ton of transactions that were bundled together and moved all at once. So for example if there were 10 billion trades in one day, it doesn't actually use any more power than if there were only 100. It's all happening at a set rate, and if your transaction is at the station in time, it can ride this train with everyone else, but if it misses the train, it waits until the next one. Think of it as if UPS ships a package, you wouldn't say it costs 10 gallons of gas to move your box from one state to another.. you'd realize that the shipping centers and trucks move a bunch of packages at the same time with yours, and this scale is what makes it profitable to do. Otherwise nobody could pay to next-day mail a package for a single person, because renting a private plane, truck and warehouse would cost thousands of dollars and your coffee maker you just bought on Amazon isn't worth that much.

2) Power costs are important to miners bottom line, so they go where power is both plentiful and cheap. Usually this means they are going somewhere like Italy, which has hydroelectric plants that produce more power than the local cities can even use. Most of the extra power would just be completely wasted because its impractical to store it anywhere and too inefficient to move it to further away areas. This is the perfect place for a bitcoin mining farm, because the power is cheap and they have more than enough to go around. The miners often use renewable energy sources like wind, solar and hydro because its cheap and often tied to government-backed projects that end up being underutilized. Sometimes, the miners are even making the investments to add new power production in an areas with very little, and whatever they don't use goes back to the local community. My point is trying to figure out the carbon emissions is insanely complex for this reason, and usually the people making the case against nfts incorrectly assume that miners are getting all the power from burning fossil fuels which is just demonstrably false. here are a few key points i will offer so you may improve your knowledge base if you wish to further work on this topic and provide deeper understanding to others:


1) Crypto mining already is a massive driver of buildout of renewable energy - specifically here in USA Solar - and is funding enormous amounts of research in this field. 2) Mining efforts consume power where there are power islands (cheap, often renewable sources of energy that are difficult to transport to where it could be put on a grid.) This activity, because mining competition is a global marketplace, drives competitors to either "hang up" their mining rigs or move their farms to find similarly cheap/infinite power. A couple cool examples here: Some of the largest bitcoin mining farms in north america are in Canada utilizing hydroelectric power that is 100% renewable, and in texas - where both solar energy buildouts and gas flaring capture technologies are being built to power mining farms and drive down carbon emissions at oil mining facilities by utilizing their unspent fuel that is otherwise a pollutant.
3) You say that energy consumption "Gets Worse" as cryptocurrencies become more popular. Why are you operating on the assumption that energy consumption is fundamentally a "bad" thing that gets "worse" instead of a "good" thing that is getting "better"? This is an error in logic. Primarily because you are failing to differentiate the counterfactual world in which cryptocurrency mining does not exist and the world in which we live - where crypto mining is driving more and more power production. The "carbon per energy" statistic you cite is for units of energy that exist before a world in which crypto mining is consuming meaningful amounts of global power - but as previously stated here - units of additional power generation that are brought online by mining activity are inherently cheap and largely renewable units of power - and thus the statistics you're employing are not apples-to-apples comparisons. One simply cannot run a bitcoin farm at high $ per kWh areas of the globe where highly polluting power sources are used vigorously to keep up with energy demand - it's not profitable and one would go bankrupt trying to mine crypto in this way. This is not the only reason that you have made a logical error here in presuming that more energy consumption = bad, though, another is:
4) The way mining farms operate raises the "floor" of energy consumption on power grids, and will always be available to consume the demanded power. Modern energy grids have pollution problems that are associated with PEAK energy demands. This means, when the grid's demand for power is expected to be high, dirtier and dirtier sources of energy are brought online to supply that power. Not only is having a strong base of always-on demand a driving force for the growth and development of more sustainable energy, but it offers an option to grid operators that did not previously exist. It is more profitable, cheaper, faster, and better for the environment for a grid to contract with a large mining facility to pay them to turn off their miners (and thus free up power) during peak demands and shortages, than it is to bring - for example - a coal power plant online to provide that same power to the grid. This option has never existed before- our best solution previously has been implementing things like rolling brownouts or burning coal and sacrificing our environment to satisfy the grid.
5) NFTs are themselves not stored on block chains. Blockchains contain pointers to where NFTs are actually stored - the entry itself is a very small JSON text entry. You do a reasonable job in this video of avoiding some of the pitfalls associated with recognizing the usefulness of NFT technology - but in and of itself it is not driving any further destruction of the environment than any other type of registration of ownership.

On the e-waste side - there are good and bad parts. Many miners use standard commodity graphics cards to mine on. Once those are no longer financially viable for mining, they're still useful to play games on, so these can be (and often are) re-sold, gaining a "second life" playing games. Sure, they won't be the latest-greatest for playing games, but they'll still have value.

The bad side is that a LOT of mining is handled on dedicated computers/processors/chips called ASICs - chips whose SOLE purpose is to mine Bitcoin (or other cryptocurrencies.) Once these are no longer financially viable for mining, they have no value for any other use - and are thrown away as e-waste. These are the terrible ones. They're also generally "better" for actual mining, since they are designed for that sole purpose, they earn more cryptocurrency for less energy than a commodity GPU.

Proof of stake should really help, since the financial incentive to create these ASICs will drop significantly.
